journal-meta.journal-title: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control

title-group.article-title: On the general second-order consensus protocol in multi-agent systems with input delays

contrib-group.aff: School of Automation, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, P.R. China

author-notes.corresp: Shengyuan Xu, School of Automation, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, Jiangsu, P.R. China Email: syxu02@yahoo.com.cn

abstract.p: In this paper we study a general consensus protocol for directed networks of double integrators with input delays. A necessary and sufficient condition is provided, under which not only the consensus is guaranteed but also the agentsâ€™ states are not exponentially diverging. Based on this condition, the delay robustness of the general protocol is analyzed. The maximal allowable upper bound of the input delay is obtained; the analysis is constructively given and different consensus modes can be regarded as special cases with different parameters. Simulation results are presented to illustrate the effectiveness of the theoretical results.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the last few years, the consensus problem of multi-agent systems has received compelling attention in the control and system community due to its broad applications in many areas such as unmanned vehicles (Beard et al. 2002), formation control (Fax and Murray 2004) and flocking (Olfati-Saber 2006). The basic objective of consensus is to design protocols based on local information of agents, which guarantee that the states of all agents converge to a common value. The consensus protocol was initially designed for systems of first-order agents (Olfati-Saber and Murray 2004; Ren and Beard 2005) and then extended to systems of second-order dynamics; see, e.g., Tian and Liu (2009), Ren and Atkins (2005), Yu et al. (2010) and references therein.

It has been shown that the first-order consensus can always be reached if certain connectivity conditions are satisfied; however, the second-order consensus relies not only on the connectivity of the communication topology but also on the parameters (or gains) of consensus protocols (Tian and Liu 2009). As a result, one critical issue in the second-order consensus problem is the characterization of the parameters of consensus protocols, i.e., finding all possible parameters which guarantee the consensus. Ren and Atkins (2005) gave a sufficient condition on parameters which depends only on the real parts of the eigenvalues of the Laplacian matrix. Based on this, Yu et al. (2010) further derived some necessary and sufficient conditions with the same second-order consensus protocol. By using the Hurwitz stability criteria, Zhu et al. (2009) studied a more general second-order consensus protocol which includes several existing protocols such as the protocol of Yu et al. (2010) as special examples. In this work, all of the gains which guarantee the consensus were obtained and the design method for protocols was constructively provided; different consensus modes can be realized by altering gains. However, the Hurwitz stability criteria may result in a comparatively complicated calculation in the analysis of stability of complex coefficient polynomials.

On the other hand, time delays may arise naturally, which are usually the key factors that influence the stability of multi-agent systems. The delay effects in multi-agent systems with first-order agents by using a frequency domain approach were studied by Olfati-Saber and Murray (2004). For the second-order consensus problem, the delay sensitivity of protocols is an important issue as well. Yu et al. (2010) extended the delay sensitivity analysis of Olfati-Saber and Murray (2004) to systems of double integrators by using a similar method. Other important works include Tian and Liu (2009) for the consensus with diverse input delays and Meng et al. (2011) for the consensus with both input and communication delays. Note that in the literature related to the delay sensitivity analysis in the consensus problem, usually protocols with particular forms are analyzed. To the best of the authorsâ€™ knowledge, up to now, however, there have been few results available for certain general protocol with which the delay sensitivity analysis can be constructively given.
This paper focuses on the general consensus protocol proposed by Zhu et al. (2009) with input delays. The major differences between this work and Zhu et al. (2009) are listed as follows:

list-item.p: In this paper, we impose a constraint on the state trajectories of agents; under the necessary and sufficient condition on protocol parameters obtained in this paper, not only is the consensus guaranteed but also the agentsâ€™ states are not exponentially diverging. This constraint is from Assumption 1 of Seo et al. (2009), under which the oscillatory and the unbounded states are allowed while the exponentially unstable ones are not allowed.

Compared with Zhu et al. (2009), where the Hurwitz stability criteria was used to indirectly analyze the stability of complex coefficient polynomials, we adopt a different method to study the parameter condition, which comparatively reduces the analysis complexity.

Zhu et al. (2009) studied the general consensus protocol without delays. In this paper, we further analyze the robustness of the protocol to input delays. The proof idea is mainly from Yu et al. 2010. However, as the delay sensitivity analysis in this paper is based on the general protocol, the results include several existing ones as special cases. By analyzing the closed-loop poles of the system, the maximal allowable upper bound of the delay is obtained.

sec.p: The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 gives the problem formulation. In Section 3, a necessary and sufficient condition on parameters is obtained and the robustness of the protocol to input delays is analyzed. Illustrative examples are presented in Section 4. Section 5 contains a brief conclusion and directions for future work.

sec.title: Problem formulation
sec.p: Let ğ’¢=(ğ’±,â„°,ğ’œ) be a weighted directed graph of order n, where ğ’±={1,â€¦,n} is the set of nodes; â„°âŠ†ğ’±Ã—ğ’± is the set of edges and ğ’œ=[ğ’œij]âˆˆRnÃ—n is the non-negative adjacency matrix. An edge of ğ’¢ is denoted by a pair of distinct nodes (i,j)âˆˆâ„°, where node i and node j are called the child node and the parent node, respectively. A path in a directed graph is a sequence i0,i1,â€¦,if of different nodes such that (ijâˆ’1,ij) is an edge for j=1,2,â€¦,f, fâˆˆZ+. Denote ğ’©i={j|(i,j)âˆˆâ„°} as the set of neighbors of node i. The adjacency matrix ğ’œ=[ğ’œij]âˆˆRnÃ—n is defined such that ğ’œij is the non-negative weight of edge (i,j). We assume ğ’œij=0 if (i,j)âˆ‰â„° and ğ’œii=0 for all iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}. The Laplacian matrix â„’=[lij]âˆˆRnÃ—n is defined as lii=âˆ‘j=1,jâ‰ inğ’œij and lij=âˆ’ğ’œij (iâ‰ j). A directed tree is a directed graph, in which there is exactly one parent for every node except for a node called the root. A directed spanning tree is a directed tree, which consists of all of the nodes in ğ’¢. A directed graph contains a directed spanning tree if there exists a directed spanning tree as a subgraph of the graph.

Let Re(z), Im(z) and âˆ¥zâˆ¥ be the real part, the imaginary part and the modulus of a complex number z, respectively. Let In (0n) be the identity (zero) matrix of dimension n and 1n be the nÃ—1 column vector of all ones. Here âŠ— represents the Kronecker product.

Lemma 2.1 (Ren and Beard 2005). Let â„’ be the Laplacian matrix corresponding to a directed graph ğ’¢. Here â„’ has exactly one zero eigenvalue and all other eigenvalues have positive real parts if and only if the directed graph ğ’¢ contains a directed spanning tree.

In this paper, we assume the network topology of the agents contains a directed spanning tree. According to Lemma 2.1, â„’ has exactly one zero eigenvalue and all other eigenvalues have positive real parts. Denote the eigenvalues of â„’ by Î¼i, i=1,â€¦,n. Without loss of generality, we assume Î¼1=0.

sec.p: In this section, we first derive a parameter condition and then study the delay sensitivity of the protocol based on the condition obtained.
To study the parameter condition, we consider system (1) under protocol (2). The Laplacian transform of (4) is

Lemma 3.2. System (1) under protocol (2) reaches consensus without exponentially diverging state trajectories if and only if Re(sij)<0, i=2,â€¦,n, j=1,2 and Re(s1j)â‰¤0, j=1,2.

Proof. Sufficiency. By Lemma 3.1, it can be seen that system (1) under protocol (2) reaches consensus if Re(sij)<0, i=2,â€¦,n, j=1,2. From (10), it is seen that the consensus mode is decided by ğ’œ. If Re(sij)<0, i=2,â€¦,n, j=1,2, is guaranteed and all of the eigenvalues of ğ’œ lie in the closed left half-plane, we can conclude that the consensus is reached and the agent trajectories are not exponentially diverging. As det (sI2âˆ’ğ’œ)=s2+k1s+k0, it follows that if Re(sij)<0, i=2,â€¦,n, j=1,2, and the roots of s2+k1s+k0=0 lie in the closed left half complex plane, system (1) under protocol (2) reaches consensus without exponentially diverging state trajectories.

Next we provide the parameter condition by the following lemma, which is based on Theorem 1 of Zhu et al. (2009) with a constraint on the state trajectories.
Lemma 3.4. System (1) under protocol (2) reaches consensus without exponentially diverging state trajectories if and only if the protocol parameters satisfy

Proof. The roots of s2+k1s+k0=0 lie in the closed left half complex plane if and only if k0â‰¥0 and k1â‰¥0. From Lemma 3.3, it is followed that Re(sij)<0, i=2,â€¦,n, j=1,2, if and only if both (13) and (14) hold. Then according to Lemma 3.2, we can conclude that system (1) under protocol (2) reaches consensus without exponentially diverging state trajectories if and only if the parameters satisfy (11)â€“(14).â€ƒâ€ƒâ–

It is easy to see that (13) and (14) are equivalent to (39) and (40) of Zhu et al. (2009), respectively. By using the stability theory of the complex coefficient polynomial, the analysis complexity is comparatively reduced.
Based on Lemma 3.4, we study the delay sensitivity of system (5) and have the following theorem.

Theorem 3.1. Suppose that (11)â€“(14) are satisfied and k0 and k1 are not simultaneously zero. If the parameters are given as k0>0 and k1=0, system (5) reaches equi-amplitude periodic consensus if and only if Ï„=0. Remark 3.1. When k0>0 and k1=0, all of the eigenvalues of ğ’œ lie on the imaginary axis and system (1) under protocol (2) reaches periodic consensus. Zhu et al. (2009) studied the periodic consensus when k2=0. However, from Lemmas 3.2 and 3.4, it can be seen that k2=0 is not a necessary condition for the periodic consensus; system (1) under protocol (2) reaches periodic consensus if and only if k0>0, k1=0, k3>0 and k2k32Re(Î¼i)Im2(Î¼i)+k32Re(Î¼i)2(k0+k2Re(Î¼i))>k22Im2(Î¼i),i=2â€¦,n.

Remark 3.2. When k0=k1=0, it is the case discussed by Yu et al. (2010), where the results are based on the assumption that k2>0 and k3>0 (where k2 and k3 are called the coupling strengths). However, Lemma 3.4 shows that the condition that k2>0 and k3>0 is necessary for the consensus.

Remark 3.3. The proof idea of Theorem 3.1 is based on that of Theorem 2 of Yu et al. (2010). However, as the case where k0=k1=0 was discussed in Yu et al. (2010), we only consider the cases where k0 and k1 are not simultaneously zero in this paper.

sec.title: Illustrative examples
sec.p: In this section, we provide numerical examples to illustrate the effectiveness of the theoretical results.
Example 4.1. Consider a group of four agents with the communication topology shown in Figure 1. The Laplacian matrix â„’ corresponding to the graph is

The eigenvalues of â„’ are Î¼1=0, Î¼2=1, Î¼3=1.5âˆ’j0.866 and Î¼4=1.5+j0.866. The initial conditions are given as x1(0)=3, x2(0)=âˆ’2, x3(0)=âˆ’1, x4(0)=4, Î½1(0)=1, Î½2(0)=âˆ’4, Î½3(0)=âˆ’3 and Î½4(0)=2.

Let k0=1, k1=1, k2=1 and k3=1. It is easy to check that (11)â€“(14) are satisfied. By Theorem 3.1, we obtain Ï„1=0.3188(s). When delays are given as Ï„=0.2(s) and Ï„=0.4(s), the trajectories of the agents are shown in Figures 2 and 3.

Let k0=1, k1=0, k2=1 and k3=1. It is easy to check that (11)â€“(14) are satisfied. By Theorem 3.1, we have that the system reaches equi-amplitude periodic consensus if and only if Ï„=0. When delays are given as Ï„=0(s) and Ï„=0.2(s), the trajectories of the agents are shown in Figures 4 and 5.

Let k0=0, k1=1, k2=1 and k3=1. It is easy to check that (11)â€“(14) are satisfied. By Theorem 3.1, we get Ï„1=0.3778(s). When delays are given as Ï„=0.3(s) and Ï„=0.5(s), the trajectories of the agents are shown in Figures 6 and 7.

sec.title: Conclusion and future work
sec.p: A general consensus protocol for directed networks of double integrators with input delays has been analyzed. A necessary and sufficient condition on protocol parameters under which not only the consensus is reached but also the agentsâ€™ states are not exponentially diverging has been given. Based on this condition, the robustness of the protocol to input delays has been discussed. The maximal allowable upper bound of the delay has been obtained. Simulation results have been presented to illustrate the effectiveness of the theoretical results. Future work includes studying the general second-order consensus protocol with both input and communication delays:

where Ï„1 and Ï„2 are input and communication delays, respectively. Meng et al. (2011) studied the consensus with both input and communication delays. Extending the results of Meng et al. (2011) to the general second-order consensus protocol (29) will be a topic of our future research.

fn.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of P.R. China (grant numbers 61074043 and 61104117), the Qing Lan Project, and the NUST Research Funding (grant number 2011ZDJH06).
